title: How to Make Chocolate Chips

steps.headline: Line two, standard-sized baking sheets with parchment paper.
steps.description: If you don't have any parchment paper, you can use wax paper instead. You will be piping the chocolate chips on these sheets.

steps.headline: Set up a double boiler.
steps.description: Fill a small pot with about 2 inches (5.08) centimeters) of water and place it on the stove. Place a heat-safe, glass bowl on top of the pot. Make sure that the bottom of the bowl is not touching the water. While it is possible to melt the baker's chocolate in the microwave, a double boiler gives you the most control. You will be less likely to scorch your chocolate.

steps.headline: Break the baker's chocolate into small pieces.
steps.description: This will make it easier to melt. Unlike most other types of chocolate, baker's chocolate is pure cocoa and does not contain any milk. This makes it ideal for vegans as well.

steps.headline: Place the ingredients into the glass bowl.
steps.description: If you want to make dark chocolate chips, omit the butter. The butter will give you richer, creamier chocolate, but it will also make the chips softer in the end. Chocolate chips made without butter will be more bitter, but they also will be less likely to melt. You can try using coconut oil instead, but keep in mind that the final chocolate chips will be soft and melt quicker. If you don't have any maple syrup, you can use finely-ground maple sugar crystals, coconut sugar crystals, or a few drops stevia instead.

steps.headline: Melt the ingredients over low to medium-low heat.
steps.description: Turn the stove on to low or medium-low heat. Stir the ingredients often until everything is melted and mixed together. Try to use a silicone spoon or spatula; the melted chocolate will not stick to that. If you are using powdered chocolate, wait until the butter melts first, then stir it in.

steps.headline: Spoon the melted mixture into a pastry bag fitted with a small tip.
steps.description: If you don't have a pastry bag, spoon the mixture into a plastic, re-sealable freezer bag. Zip the bag shut tightly, then snip off one of the corners at the bottom. Don't snip off too much, or you will get chocolate "kisses" instead of "chips."

steps.headline: Start piping the chocolate onto the parchment lined baking sheet.
steps.description: To create the points, lightly touch the center of the chip with a toothpick. Lift the toothpick up and away.

steps.headline: Wait for the chocolate chips to harden.
steps.description: This may take a while, depending on how warm it is in your kitchen. To speed up the process, put the baking sheets inside your freezer for about half an hour.

steps.headline: Store the chocolate chips in an air-tight container in the freezer.
steps.description: When you are ready to use them, simply take the container out, and pick out what you need.

steps.description: If you can't find any cacao butter, you can use coconut butter instead.

steps.headline: Melt the butter over low to medium-low heat.
steps.description: Stir it every so often with a silicone spoon or spatula so that it melts evenly.

steps.headline: Stir in the rest of your ingredients.
steps.description: You don't have to add in the raw cashew/macadamia butter, or the dry milk powder, if you are having troubles finding them. These ingredients simply help make the white chocolate chips even creamier.

steps.headline: Transfer the melted mixture into a pastry bag fitted with a small tip.
steps.description: If you don't have one, a plastic, re-sealable freezer bag. Spoon the mixture into the bag, then zip the bag shut tightly. Snip one of the corners at the bottom, and you have a makeshift pastry bag. Don't snip off too much, however, or you will get chocolate "kisses" instead of "chips."

steps.headline: Pipe the mixture onto the baking sheet.
steps.description: To make the points, gently touch the center of the chips with a toothpick. Lift the toothpick upwards.

steps.headline: Wait for the chocolate chips to harden, or put them into your freezer.
steps.description: It will take about half an hour for the chips to harden in your freezer.

steps.headline: Keep the white chocolate chips in an air-tight container in the freezer.
steps.description: When you are ready to use them, simply pull the container out, and take what you need.
